headline: BUS SYSTEM PUSHING OUTWARD
leadPara: Adecade ago,'' said County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, ''we were looking at a county that really had no transportation, internally, by way of buses, to speak of, except those buses which were serving the densely populated cities.'' Mr. DelBello, in a recent reflection on changes in Westchester's transportation picture, noted accomplishments over the last decade and attempted to identify suburban transportation trends. ''If there's an identifiable trend,'' he said, ''I think it is the development of the paratransit system.'' This system, he explained, is a ''second level'' of bus services beyond the fixed routes that tie major population centers together and into the more sparsely settled regions.

headline: General Jarvis Rides Again
leadPara: It's been two years since California's voters fired the first big volley for a national tax revolt - a constitional amendment to cut their local property taxes by more than 50 percent. The paint has begun to peel off some schoolhouse walls, and public libaries have cut their hours. Yet, all in all, thanks to a $6-billion state reserve, the $7 billion in cuts precipitated by Proposition 13 have not yet been disastrous. Emboldened by victory at Lexington, the commander-in-chief of Proposition 13, Howard Jarvis, is moving on Concord with a still bigger weapon. Proposition 9 on the California ballot tomorrow would further amend the state constitution to cut income tax rates in half. In one blow, the state treasury would lose an additional $4 billion or more. The prospect has sent a new shiver down the spines of municipal leaders, who know that they will be the main casualties.

headline: TO TOUCH MORE LIFE
leadPara: HELEN AND TEACHER The Story of Helen Keller and Anne Sullivan Macy. By Joseph P. Lash. Illustrated. 811 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $17.95. JOSEPH LASH's ''Helen and Teacher'' is part of the Radcliffe biography series about distinguished American women. It's a risky book in two respects. First of all, the lives of Helen Keller and her teacher Anne Sullivan Macy have already been told. Helen Keller wrote ''The Story of My Life'' and ''Teacher: Anne Sullivan Macy,'' and Nella Braddy did a good biography of Mrs. Macy in the 1930's. And William Gibson dramatized the story in his wonderful play ''The Miracle Worker.'' A second risk is that any book this long - 811 pages, to be exact - is bound to be put in the company of all those fat and mindless biographies we've been getting recently.

headline: KARL RICHTER DEFENDS HIS WAY WITH BACH
leadPara: Many people think innocently of classical music as a realm of timeless masterpieces, immune to the ripples of fashion that make popular music so fickle. But fashions flourish in classical music, too - not so obviously but perhaps even more insidiously. Take the case of Karl Richter, who will be conducting a Bach and Handel program at Avery Fisher Hall this Friday, as part of the Basically Bach Festival. Mr. Richter has an honored name among Baroque enthusiasts for his many fine concert tours and recordings. His concert Friday is almost sure to be direct and honest in a manner that will give most members of the audience a taste of ''timelessness.'' But it is possible to see in Mr. Richter's career the rise and fall of a whole style of Baroque performance, one that seemed revolutionary 25 years ago and seems old-fashioned today. Mr. Richter is fully aware of that drama, and bitter about it.

headline: A FILM TRIBUTE TO 1930'S JAZZ IN KANSAS CITY
leadPara: Idreamed I went back to Kansas City and stood on 18th and Vine,'' sings Big Joe Turner near the beginning of Bruce Ricker's film about Kansas City jazz, ''The Last of the Blue Devils,'' which has its New York premiere Wednesday at the Art Theater, Eighth Street and University Place. ''I shook hands with Piney Brown, and I just couldn't keep from crying.'' Unless one is a jazz historian, one doesn't know at this point who Piney Brown was (he was a black bartender who lent money to many jazz musicians), but one doesn't have to know to feel the mixture of poignancy and pride Mr. Turner is expressing. The Kansas City the singer remembers was a thriving Depression era metropolis where an entrenched political machine allowed bars, gambling dens, and bordellos to operate around the clock, thus providing work for hundreds of jazz musicians. As the film soon makes clear, with shots of boarded-up storefronts, pawn shops, and vacant lots near today's 18th and Vine, that Kansas City no longer exists; thus the poignancy. But there's ample reason for Mr. Turner's pride. Together with musicians like Lester Young, Charlie Parker, Count Basie and Jay McShann, he helped create some of the finest and most innovative jazz and blues America has produced.

abstract: Thomas Conrad-Cynthia Arnson article scores America's 'nonlethal' military aid for military-civilian junta (M)

headline: THE AID FOR EL SALVADOR IS CALLED NONLETHAL
leadPara: Carter Administration officials, when pressing Congress for passage of $5.7 million in emergency military assistance for El Salvador on March 25, insisted that the request was for ''nonlethal'' equipment that ''will help strengthen the Army's key role in reforms.'' The package was approved a week later. According to Congressional testimony on March 25 by Franklin D. Kramer, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, the aid would consist of $3.7 million for trucks and transport vehicles, $316,000 for riot-control gear, $1.2 million for communications equipment, and $400,000 for ''various other equipment to include trailers.'' The rest of the outlay was for transporting the materiel. What Mr. Kramer neglected to disclose in his public testimony was that the aid package in fact included combat-related equipment that stretches the definition of ''nonlethal'' beyond credibility. The Defense Security Assistance Agency had provided Congress with a list of the items in the military-aid proposal that was more detailed than the one made public by Mr. Kramer. The members of Congress who saw the list - it was given to the House and Senate Appropriations Committees, the House Foreign Affairs Committee and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee - accepted the ''nonlethal'' designation despite the nature of the equipment. When this gear reaches the field, however, any distinction between lethal and nonlethal will have been lost. As repression by Salvadoran security forces escalates daily in the countryside, this gear becomes vital to the junta's waging of counterinsurgency war. Under the Freedom of Information Act, the American Friends Service Committee has obtained copies of the ''Letters of Offer and Acceptance'' from the Department of the Army that detail the military aid approved by Congress. To be delivered (some equipment is en route, the Army says) are 7,500 CS tear-gas grenades, 250 ''Manpack'' field combat radios, thousands of batteries, and an unspecified number of tear-gas-grenade launchers. The sale of 50 portable PVS-2B night-vision devices blurs the supposed distinction between lethal and nonlethal weapons: These electro-optic devices are used for observation and nighttime weapons targeting. Night-vision-weapons technology and related equipment like the 12 ''Image Intensifiers,'' also included, were perfected for use in Vietnam. To help security forces preserve so-called law and order, the Administration is sending three communications-monitoring sets at more than $38,000 each. An Army aide says that security forces will use them to monitor the airwaves and track the exact locations of clandestine-radio transmitters: ''It's perfect for use against guerrillas and insurgents.''

headline: Obituary 5 -- No Title
RABBI BERNARD J. BAMBERGER, 76
leadPara: Dr. Bernard J. Bamberger, a scholar of Reform Judaism and rabbi emeritus of Temple Shaaray Tefila, died Saturday at Doctors Hospital after suffering a heart attack in his Manhattan home. He was 76 years old. Rabbi Bamberger had been head of Temple Shaaray Tefila from 1944 until his retirement in 1971, when he was succeeded by Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum. The temple this year is observing its 135th anniversary and is one of New York City's oldest and most prominent Reform Jewish synagogues.

headline: Cape Town Riots On Anniversary Of Soweto
leadPara: Thousands of South Africa's nonwhites rioted last week on the fourth anniversary of the outbreaks that left more than 600 dead in the black township of Soweto, near Johannesburg. This time, however, most of the violence was in suburban ghettos housing many of Cape Town's 500,000 workers of mixed-race ancestry. The Government had banned assemblies of more than 10 persons. But youths gathered in the drab, grassless towns of Ravensmead and Elsie's River to stone cars and block roads, and then turned to looting and burning that destroyed property valued at millions of dollars.

headline: REGGAE:THIRD WORLD
leadPara: Reggae arose as a form of Jamaican folk music, and its dancing vitality captivated not only the island, but also the British West Indian community and, through it, rock-and-roll. Reggae started out as a mixture of American black popular music and the offbeat rhythmic accents characteristic of the Caribbean. But it soon developed its own forms of progressivism, mainly African influences and the innovations of Jamaican studio wizards, who made up in originality what they lacked in technical fanciness. The result has been a music that is strange and still primitive, and it has had a profound impact on new-wave rock. Third World, headliner at concerts Thursday at the Beacon Theater and Saturday at Brooklyn College, purveys a different kind of reggae progressivism, and it made a striking contrast with the other reggae act on the bill, Toots and the Maytals. Third World is like some reggae variant of a jazz-rock outfit on the order of Spyro Gyra or a progressive-rock group like Boston or, perhaps most aptly, the Cuban fusion group, Irakere.

headline: 1960's band of Robert Fripp rematerializes.
leadPara: THE League of Gentlemen was the name of the first band Robert Fripp ever belonged to, back in Dorset, England, in the early 1960's. It is also, however, a band for the 1980's, once more including Mr. Fripp. It will play tonight and tomorrow night at Irving Plaza - and again, it now seems, in New York clubs for a couple of days in mid-July. Mr. Fripp has had an interesting career over the last decade. He led one of the most cultishly admired of the early-70's British progressive-rock bands, King Crimson. After that group's final concert, in Central Park on July 1, 1974, Mr. Fripp retreated into personal study, to re-emerge a few years later as a fascinating solo guitarist and record producer. And now, for the first time in six years, he has a new band.

headline: LETTER TO A RICH FRIEND
leadPara: I am writing to thank you for a most enjoyable weekend at your cottage on the Maine coast. Let me continue the dialogue we began by fleshing out the ''radical'' thought that so distressed you - my suggestion that your political formula for perpetuation of the good life is hardly likely to ensure even your own prosperity. I am convinced that you face many serious problems - not from anything the weak and divided American left may do, but from an economy out of control and a business leadership too ossified to achieve even its own survival. I remember your recounting to me some recent deliberations of the Business Council. These debates struck me as little more than narrow Jesuitical wrangling while the Church burns. You and your colleagues worried about whether President Carter's budget cuts were deep enough and whether the Federal Reserve would have the guts to keep the money supply tight. If our prosperity could be restored by a neat adjustment in the discount rate or the Federal budget, someone would have done it long ago.

headline: Sussex Weighing Land-Use Project
leadPara: IT'S REALLY not hard to do land-use planning in harmony with natural systems,'' Karl Kehde said. ''The problem is that it's usually not lawful to do so.'' As a land-use planner, developer and conservationist, Mr. Kehde has been involved for the last two years in an effort to create an environmentally sound community on a 300-acre site in Frankford Township, Sussex County. His plan incorporates a number of elements which, if not highly complex technologically, certainly represent a radical departure from either a standard subdivision or a condominium proposal.

headline: ROCK:NEW FRIPP BANMD IN DEBUT
leadPara: THE New York debut Friday night at the Irving Plaza of Robert Fripp's new band, the League of Gentlemen, was a demonstrable success as far as the audience was concerned - even if that sort of success might seem an ironic one for Mr. Fripp. He did disband his last group, King Crimson, after complaining bitterly about the star system in rock-and-roll, and ever since he has been espousing a small-isbeautiful, humbler-than-thou philosophy. But Friday looked like old-fashioned rock-star hero worship all over again. The League of Gentlemen seems an unabashed showcase for Mr. Fripp. Every time he grimaced, people would raise their fists in the air and howl. And to obtain an encore, they resorted to a steady ''Fripp-Fripp-Fripp'' chant. So much for Mr. Fripp's self-amused, sometimes contradictory search for self-effacement.

headline: FUN AND FIREWORKS FROM POINT LOOKOUT TO PLAYLAND TO PLAINFIELD
leadPara: Westchester's sixth annual fiddling celebration on Sunday, which is expectied to attract 10,000 people, will be the county's major event in a weekend of holiday activities. It will take place from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. at the Ward Pound Reservation in northern Westchester. There is no charge to hear the folk music, but parking cost $2 ($1 with a county park pass). The music, featuring 17 of the best fiddling groups in the nation, will radiate from a stand under an old oak tree at the lake-site picnic area. Ward Pound Ridge, a vast park with hiking trails lean-to camping and fishing, is in Cross River, N.Y., at the intersection of Routes 35 and 121. It is accessible from Exit 6 of Interstate 684.

Most of the layoffs have occurred in American-owned plants, and for Ed Broadbent, leader of the New Democratic Party, the Socialist third force in Canada, there is a lesson in all the bad economic news.
abstract: Ontario is being hit hard by job layoffs as recession in US spreads north; most layoffs have occured in American-owned plants; Ed Broadbent, leader of New Democratic Party, addressing party meeting in Guelph, suggested as solution Canadian industry owned and controlled by Canadians; Liberal Party, at convention in Winnipeg, is expected to adopt strongly nationalistic economic stand; Herbert E Gray, Min of Industry, Trade and Commerce, is preparing document for release in fall outlining industrial strategy with heavy emphasis on economic and technological independence (M)

headline: CANADIANS RESISTING U.S. ECONOMIC ROLE
leadPara: Ontario, Canada's most important industrial province, is being hit hard by job layoffs as the recession in the United States spreads north of the border. Most of the layoffs have occurred in American-owned plants, and for Ed Broadbent, leader of the New Democratic Party, the Socialist third force in Canada, there is a lesson in all the bad economic news. Mr. Broadbent explained the lesson at a party meeting in Guelph two weeks ago: ''Surely it's time to set in motion the only feasible long-term solution: Canadian industry owned and controlled by Canadians.''

headline: FOR SHIPYARD-SAFETY CRITIC, IDEALISM HAS A HIGH PRICE
leadPara: GRISWOLD RICHARD B. PROESCHER lives way out in the woods, over rickety bridges and behind a clump of pine trees. Inside his medium-sized white Cape Cod home, he is trying to help raise his two daughters, pay his wife's medical bills, write a college paper and edit a series of controversial broadsides attacking alleged safety problems at the giant shipyard that dismissed him more than a year ago. The 43-year-old Mr. Proescher may be a member of a rare species: the full-time, uncompromising, dyed-in-the-wool do-gooder. Either that, or, as a spokesman for his former employer labeled him, he is ''a maverick, plain and simple.'' ''He's part of a vanishing breed all right,'' said the official, who asked not to be identified, ''but I'm not sure I'd call him a dogooder. What good has he ever done? Nobody pays any attention to that newspaper he puts out.''

leadPara: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 6--Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and his Liberal Party ended a convention here today after setting a collision course with the country's provinces over constitutional and energy policy.
abstract: Trudeau and his Liberal Party end convention in Winnipeg after reaffirming doctrine of strong central government able to override narrow provincial interests; Trudeau says he will make good his pledge for new constitution to replace British North America Act; several provinces, notably Quebec, are opposed to 'patriation' of constitution until new sharing of powers has been agreed to and new amending formula established; 2d major conflict concerns pricing and sharing of country's oil and gas supplies, which are concentrated in west, mainly Alberta; Trudeau and Premier Peter Lougheed of Alberta are to meet to try to settle what has become 1 of Canada's most divisive political and economic issues; Alberta has linked constitutional and energy problems by threatening to hold up any changes in charter until it gets satisfaction on new energy pricing package; Trudeau and Energy Min Marc Lalonde appear in no mood to compromise at conference on their basic belief that Canada's energy resources should benefit all Canadians (M)

headline: TRUDEAU IS SET ON COLLISION COURSE WITH PROVINCES OVER CONSTITUTION
leadPara: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and his Liberal Party ended a convention here today after setting a collision course with the country's provinces over constitutional and energy policy. A summer and autumn of conflict were in prospect as Mr. Trudeau and the party reaffirmed the doctrine of a strong central government able to override narrow provincial interests. Mr. Trudeau, who led the party back to power in February after a nine-month interlude with the Progressive Conservatives at the reins, was given a strong vote of confidence.

headline: Woman Is Murdered In Luxury Building
leadPara: A 46-year-old woman was found stabbed to death in her East Side luxury apartment late last night, the police said. The woman, Leslie Blackman, was found by the police at 10:30 P.M., fully clothed, lying on her living room floor in Apartment 3D at 227 East 66th Street. She had been stabbed many times, but there was no sign of a struggle, a police spokesman said. He said that someone had called the 911 emergency number to summon officers to Miss Blackman's apartment, but he had no further details on the murder. Not So Close a Call For 2 Private Planes Because of a controller error, two private planes bound for La Guardia Airport passed about a mile and a half from one another yesterday about 17 miles northeast of the field, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. The rules required a minimum separation of three miles. A spokesman for the agency said the pilot of one of the planes, a Cessna twin-engine craft, had told controllers that the other plane, a twin Piper, had gone by at the same altitude.

headline: Jessica Lange since 'Kong' and 'Jazz.'
leadPara: HAVING played opposite a gorilla in her first film, the remake of ''King Kong,'' and the angel of death in her second, ''All That Jazz,'' Jessica Lange is glad to have a chance to be a person instead of a presence in her third and fourth films. These are ''How to Beat the High Cost of Living,'' which opens today at New York theaters (see review on page C10), and a remake of ''The Postman Always Rings Twice,'' adapted from the James M. Cain novel of lust and murder. It is scheduled for release during the Christmas holidays, with Jack Nicholson and Miss Lange playing the roles created by John Garfield and Lana Turner.

headline: PONTIFF CAUTIONS BRAZIL'S BISHOPS TO STRESS GOSPEL
leadPara: Pope John Paul II told a gathering of the bishops of Brazil today that in their zeal for promoting social progress they were neglecting the need to spread the Gospel. The Pope spent eight hours meeting with 220 of the 260 active bishops of the Brazilian church in an encounter aimed at defining Rome's views of the independent-minded institution's activist role in the country's life.

headline: Peter Gabriel, late of Genesis.
leadPara: IT'S been five years since Peter Gabriel left Genesis. Since his departure, that band has sustained its commercial success admirably, despite all the prognostications of disaster that accompanied the loss of its lead singer. Mr. Gabriel hasn't done quite so well in the marketplace. But he has broadened and deepened his artistic impact with three fine solo albums, all of them titled ''Peter Gabriel.'' The third and latest was rejected by Atlantic as insufficiently commercial, and has now appeared on the Mercury label. It is a superior record. Mr. Gabriel, who will sing at the Diplomat Hotel tomorrow night, has the rare gift of being able to experiment and alter his musical and poetic sytles without losing focus; his originality is so powerful that it all, somehow, hangs together.

headline: DEEPER INTO THE BOG
leadPara: GETTING THROUGH By John McGahern. 172 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $10.95. JOHN MCGAHERN, born in 1934, is probably the most accomplished Irish novelist of his generation. Yet ''Getting Through,'' 11 short stories of which three were previously published in The New Yorker and the remainder in British periodicals, is quite uneven and seldom shows Mr. McGahern working to the height of his talent. One remembers his fine first novel, ''The Barracks'' (1962), for its dark portrayal of vindictiveness in the hateful feuding of a policeman with his superior, for the unusual sensitivity and fullness with which a stepmother's domestic unhappiness and grave illness were rendered, and for its representation of Irish country life as a petty hell of tedium and of self- and mutual thwarting.

headline: BOTH BRAZIL AND THE POPE HAVE A CHOICE:CHURCH OR STATE
leadPara: Helder Camara, known as ''the red bishop,'' has long been used to seeing the walls of his house daubed with painted charges of being a Communist, and has seldom expected official approval. The diminutive 71-year-old cleric almost got lost in the billowing white-robed clutch of the Pontiff, but the point didn't escape the cheering hundreds of thousands in Recife and the millions following the papal journey on television.

headline: MOYNIHAN'S FEEBLE CASE ON U.S. AID TO STATES
leadPara: To the Editor: Senator Moynihan has just released his annual report on the ''shortchanging'' of New York State by Washington, claiming that ''the Federal Government is no bargain for New York.''f Federal taxes and spending were balanced in each state, the important redistributional aspects of fiscal policy would be undermined. For example, progressive income taxes take more from the wealthy than they do from the poor. Similarly, many Federal transfer programs are designed to raise the incomes of the nation's lowest socioeconomic groups. Because per capita income in the Northeast, including New York State, is above the national average, our progressive tax system generates higher tax payments per person from this region. In the South, where per capita income remains at 87 percent of the non-South, the Federal tax system generates fewer dollars per person.

headline: Is British rock more hip than American?
leadPara: AMERICAN rock-and-rollers live in a continual state of nervous submission to the English, encouraged in this curious posture by a few die-hard American rock Anglophiles. It's a curious paradox. For centuries America struggled to free itself from excessive European influence. Rock is an indigenous American musical form. Yet the British have appropriated it, and American rock intellectuals prostrate themselves before the appropriations. This is hardly to say that Britain has not produced significant rock music. The best of the potentially commercial new British rockers - Elvis Costello and the Clash among them - are first-rate, and such vanguard British groups as the Gang of Four or the Young Marble Giants are equally admirable.

headline: Those Little Laws Count
leadPara: Without making a Federal case of it, New York ought to rally its scarce resources for a vigorous campaign against the so-called trivial crimes. Where the social order is held together as much by Scotch tape, good sense and good luck as by the law, the progressive violation of ''little'' codes and regulations can be not only annoying but costly and damaging. The disease spreads. If illegal peddlers still crowd the midtown sidewalks six months after the police advertise a crackdown against them, why should anyone be surprised that the drivers of the horsedrawn carriages in Central Park charge more than the regulations on their hidden rate cards allow? If, despite a move against them, young men are allowed to destroy the peace of a summer night with the blare of their huge shoulder-strap radios, is it really any wonder that some cabbies hustle innocent visitors?

headline: GALLERY VIEW PONDERING THE PATH OF DERAIN
leadPara: In every history of 20th-century art there is someone who doesn't quite fit. More often than not that someone is Andre Derain, the French painter who was born 100 years ago last month. Just about everyone agrees that in the first 10 years of this century Derain made a most auspicious beginning and was the preferred companion of more than one man of unquestioned genius. Majority opinion says that thereafter he opted out of the adventure, kept to himself, and settled for a staid and undemanding conservatism. Minority opinion blows up at this point and says that in a world of hucksters and opportunists Derain went his own way, set an example of probity and high conscience, and will come into his own when sanity is restored to the earth. That Derain began well can hardly be questioned. Born to rich parents in the Parisian suburb of Chatou, he was free to read what he liked, go to museums whenever he pleased (all the time, that is to say) and in general indulge his superabundant curiosity. He was tremendously and unmistakably bright. He was one of the biggest men that anyone had ever seen, and he had energy and endurance to match. He could eat and drink for three hours at lunchtime, walk 12 miles to the next town, beat all comers in the single sculls at the local regatta, and walk back home with the heavy silver cup in his arms.

headline: THE POP LIFE
leadPara: THE careers of Bryan Ferry and Roxy Music have had their ups and downs. Roxy Music emerged early in the last decade as one of the most striking new British progressive-rock bands, poised between the grand affectations of older art rock and the stylish affectations of the new wavers yet to come. But after Brian Eno left the band and a few more hit albums had followed, Mr. Ferry went out on his own - a move that proved more rewarding artistically than financially. Last year the post-Eno Roxy Music re-formed, but the reunion album, ''Manifesto,'' was a disappointing blend of old Roxy Music mannerisms and disco trendiness.

headline: 1915 DREAM TICKET
leadPara: To the Editor: For the benefit of historical purists (and tonguein-cheek historians), Gerald Ford was not the first former President to reject a bid to run for Vice President because his conditions were not met. On Oct. 15, 1915, Theodore Roosevelt wrote his friend George W. Perkins:$''I note your sinister attempt to get me to offer to go as Vice-President on a Progressive ticket with Wilson as President. While there is much that is attractive in the proposition, I am afraid that I must decline; but if you will substitute Mrs. (Edith Bolling) Galt for her somewhat frigid fiance (Wilson), I will consider the matter!'' MAX M. MINTZ Professor of History Southern Connecticut State College New Haven, July 20, 1980

headline: The Chicken Little Syndrome
leadPara: Why are soothsayers so relentlessly pessimistic these days? Not so many years ago, prophets regularly expressed confidence in the future. Now they all seem to fear the ''worst case.'' There were enough dire predictions at last week's futurology conference in Toronto to unnerve heroes. Economic depression. Nuclear war. Starvation. Tyranny. Fanaticism. And if those weren't grim enough, the Carter Administration issued its own ''Global 2000 Report,'' a projection of environmental and population stresses that will soon afflict human life if present trends continue. The problems were described as ''disturbing,'' ''alarming,'' nothing less than an erosion of the earth's biological carrying capacity and ''progressive degradation and impoverishment'' of its natural resources.

headline: POP:KENNY LOGGINS AND FIREFALL STRUT STUFF AT DR PEPPER FESTIVAL
leadPara: KENNY LOGGINS and his band and the group Firefall, who were at the Dr Pepper festival in Central Park on Monday, both used to play something called country-rock. The label may have been useful at one time, but it was never really adequate; now it's utterly irrelevant. Mr. Loggins's band includes musicians who play English horn, bass clarinet, flutes and various saxophones, and several of his arrangements call for thick synthesizer textures. Firefall's music ranges from lightly country-flavored numbers to moderately convincing hard rock to the sort of disciplined harmony singing pop groups like the Association used to purvey. This stuff isn't ''country-rock,'' it's today's mainstream popular music. Mr. Loggins, who used to be half of the Loggins-Messina duo and has gone on to continuing commercial success as a solo artist, has always been a little too breathy, a little too sweet for this listener. But there's no denying that he has tackled a broad range of pop styles, from country to rockabilly to blue-eyed soul to something approximating English progressive rock, and presumably he hass broadened his audience's tastes in the process. He's too concerned with his selling points to abandon the informal, just-me-and-you-all solo interludes that have always figured in his presentations; these interludes present him at his breathiest, sweetest and most vulnerable, and his fans love them. But with each album and each tour he hass ventured into additional musical idioms, and while to these ears he's not particularly convincing when he's singing material influenced by soul or hard rock, at least he isn't standing still.

headline: A BOOMING ALBERTA BOILS ON OIL PRICES
leadPara: There appears to be a building crane on every downtown street of Alberta's two main cities, Edmonton, the capital, and Calgary, the center of the fast-growing oil and gas industry. Despite the boom times there is also anger and frustration. The targets of these feelings are Ottawa, the federal capital, and Toronto and Montreal, the financial and industrial centers of central Canada. A week ago Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Premier Peter Lougheed of Alberta parted company without reaching agreement on how to price Alberta's oil and gas or how to share their benefits, and the anger that has developed is considered highly dangerous for the uneasy Canadian federation.

headline: Westchester/This Week; THEATER MUSIC AND DANCE ART LECTURE FILMS CHILDREN MISCELLANEOUS IN NEARBY ROCKLAND
A SLIPPERY SUBJECT
leadPara: OIL, WAR, AND AMERICAN SECURITY The Search for a National Policy on Foreign Oil, 1941-1947. By Michael B. Stoff. 249 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $15. ACCESS to crude oil and security of supply are not new concerns, but they were not particularly visible issues in the United States during the 1950's and 1960's because the system that emerged after World War II was working quite well. The combination of public and private interests assured the flow of oil and kept political encroachment at bay. An important part of the answer to the puzzling problem of how this postwar system led the Western nations to become overdependent on Middle Eastern oil is provided in ''Oil, War, and American Security'' by Michael Stoff, an assistant professor of history at the University of Texas. The book concerns the interaction of the United States Government and the American oil companies during World War II and the postwar expansion of American influence in the Middle East. The central role of oil became apparent to American leaders when the war created enormous energy demands that were met out of American reserves. (The Allied military effort used seven billion barrels, six billion of which came from American wells.) Three important policy concerns emerged during the war and the immediate postwar period. The first was howto conserve United States oil resources and encourage foreign production. Most of the policy makers recognized that American reserves were insufficient for the United States to continue to be the world's main supplier, let alone to be in a position to ''oil another war,'' as Secretary of the Interior Harold Ickes put it.

headline: AFTER POLITICS, THERE'S ROCK, DISCO OR POP CLUBS TO VISIT
leadPara: MANHATTAN may not boast a particularly diverse range of pop concerts this week, but the city's club life for youthful forms of popular music remains more active and varied than anywhere else. Unlike some forms of music, the seasonal cycle doesn't affect pop concerts all that much. During convention week some halls are out of circulation for pop - Madison Square Garden, of course, and the Palladium, one of New York's leading rock theaters. But there is the 15-year-old outdoor-concert series in the old Wollman Skating Rink in the southwestern corner of Central Park. This week, the series, which is sponsored by Dr Pepper, offers Todd Rundgren's Utopia tonight and tomorrow night, the Ramones on Monday and Melissa Manchester on Wednesday. Shows are at 6:30 P.M., tickets cost $3 and $5 and the information number is 249-8870.

headline: MUSKIE, IN DEPARTURE FROM PRACTICE, ASSAILS REPUBLICAN CRITICISM
leadPara: Asserting that he was ''the first political Secretary of State in a long time,'' Edmund S. Muskie began a series of speeches around the country today by accusing the Republicans of advocating ''a foreign policy of reaction'' and of practicing ''partisan doubletalk.'' In recent years Secretaries of State have avoided partisan speeches in election campaigns, but the former Maine Senator, himself a Vice-Presidential nominee in 1968 and a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1972, has decided to travel around the country to seek support for the Carter Administration's policies and to rebut Republican criticism.

headline: by Harris Wofford
leadPara: After he hit bottom in his campaign last winter, Edward M. Kennedy passed one test of character. He did not run away. He fought his way back up, on his own, with personal perseverance and courage, without help from the Kennedy myth. Now he faces a harder test. Will he do what Joseph Kennedy taught his sons not to do: put aside the aim of being No. 1 and put himself at the service of a larger cause? In the final days before the balloting in New York City, will he do what neither of his brothers ever did: commit himself and all his forces to nominating someone else - someone who has a better chance than he or Mr. Carter of uniting the party and the country, and of beating Ronald Reagan?

headline: POINT OF VIEW THE MANY FACES OF THE COMING TAX CUT
leadPara: The American taxpayer, who has shown little interest in a tax cut and much more enthusiasm for a balanced budget, is likely nevertheless to get a tax cut - or, more specifically, a smaller tax increase next year. He will not get the balanced budget he longs for as an antidote to inflation despite the painfully extracted budget cuts this year. The recession has increased Government expenditures and will shrink tax revenues even without a tax cut. Inflation will still be with him. Unless the recession lasts longer than most forecasts project, it is too late for tax measures to cushion its impact. But they can bring a faster, sharper recovery and in the long run help increase investment. Once the size, cost and probable investment and consumption effects are known, it is possible to make a more informed selection among the proposals now being promoted.

headline: OIL OUTPUT IN U.S. PICKING UP
leadPara: Oil production in the 48 contiguous states rose in July, compared with July of 1979, according to estimates released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. The trade association's monthly figures marked the first such improvement in more than three years. And although the low July 1979 output was something of an aberration, the comparison was the most convincing evidence to date that the burst of drilling stimulated by last year's decision to decontrol the price of crude oil has begun to check the decline in oil production in the ''lower 48'' states.

headline: The Marriage Penalty
leadPara: Angela and David Boyter had a problem. Under present law, as married people with separate (and substantial) incomes, they had to pay several thousand dollars more each year to the Internal Revenue Service than if they had remained single. Their solution: an amicable divorce each December, remarriage each January. Now, a tax court has ruled that the Boyters still have a problem. While the court avoided addressing the issue directly, it seems that a divorce based solely on the desire to avoid taxes is no divorce at all. Only Congress, it appears, can undo the ''marriage penalty'' And even that is not certain, for lurking beneath the surface of this seemingly straightforward issue are some thorny questions of tax equity.

headline: STUDY DEFINES TROJAN WAR TERRAIN
leadPara: A TEAM of American and Turkish geologists has uncovered sedimentary evidence establishing the lay of the land around ancient Troy and suggesting that events of the Trojan War described by Homer occurred in a far different geographic setting from that assumed by most archeologists. If there is a historic basis to the Trojan War - a big if, in the opinion of many classical scholars -then the Greek forces probably did not anchor in a bay off the Dardanelles and march south to lay siege to the fortified city, as had been assumed. Instead, according to the new interpretation, they may have landed at the Besika embayment off the Aegean Sea to the west, marched south and east and then attacked across a plain southeast of Troy.

headline: Stephen F. Cohen;  HARD-LINE FALLACIES
leadPara: Despite a long history of intellectual sterility, failures abroad, and ugly consequences at home, the vaunted hard line toward the Soviet Union is ascendant again. Cold warriors, bolstered by election-year excesses in Afghanistan, dominate the Carter Administration and Republican opposition alike. President Carter and Ronald Reagan race forward with new nuclear strategies and weapons systems - all under the worn hard-line banners of countering the ''Soviet menace,'' military superiority and ''credible deterrents.'' Support for the idea that nuclear war is unthinkable, for parity, mutual constraint and SALT II is lost in the clamor. Pro-detente politics, always unstable in the United States, is in disarray. It is time, before we rush into a cold war II and a newly escalated arms race that portend new tragedies in the 1980's, to look more carefully at the self-professed ''realism'' of this tenacious hard line. Many of its cherished axioms, actually serious misconceptions about the nature of the Soviet Union, are contradicted by a large body of scholarly knowledge. Five fallacies of the hard line are especially important:

headline: HOW TO END THE INEQUITYTo the Editor:$
leadPara: Your editorial on the marriage penalty suffers the common flaw of most tax proposals these days. Working married couples, The Times declares, need a tax break to offset the cost of a housekeeper. Conservatives promise to whip inflation now if we only lower taxes on investment income. And liberals promise a society of solar heating, hydroelectric power and small cars if only the tax code could be restructured. How much more complicated, unfair and unworkable must we make the tax code before it dawns on us that this is an extremely costly and ineffective tool of social and economic policy. Taxes are only good at raising revenues, and the fairest way to raise them is to treat all income and all households alike, according to a simple, progressive scale: no deductions, no credits, no mess. STEVEN PEARLSTEIN, West Newbury, Mass., Aug. 17, 1980

VIEWS OF SPORT MAGIC OF GRAND SLAMS ENDURES IN WORLD OF TENNIS
leadPara: BJORN BORG resumes his third quest this week toward achieving the ultimate goal of all tennis champions - the Grand Slam. First you should know that, to accomplish a Grand Slam in tennis, a player must win the sport's four most prominent singles titles: Wimbledon and the United States, Australian and French opens - in the same year. As he has done two other times, Borg is entering the United States Open having won at Paris and Wimbledon. In more than a century of tennis, only two men have achieved this: J. Donald Budge (United States) in 1938, and Rodney G. Laver (Australia) in 1962 and again in 1969. Their counterparts in the women's game have also been American and Australian: Maureen (Little Mo) Connolly (United States) in 1953, and Margaret Court (Australia) in 1970.

headline: A Camp Where Adults Recapture the Past; Camp Where Adults Can Recapture Past
leadPara: KENT, Conn. THE camper hopped off the giant bus that had brought him to the woods of northwestern Connecticut. He had short-cropped dark hair and he wore glasses. A baseball cap sat lop sided on his head. He carried a tennis racquet with his one sports jacket hooked onto the frame. He was grinning.

headline: Victor Lebow, Marketing Official And Activist in Civil Rights Here
leadPara: Victor Lebow, a former advertising and marketing consultant, died of of a heart ailment yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan. He was a former vice president of the Kyser-Roth Corporation and a former director of Faberge. He retired in the late 1950's. Since his retirement he had been active in the civil-rights movement. He was the author of a book entitled ''Free Enterprise, the Opium of the American People,'' and a frequent contributor to such magazines as The Nation, Challenge and The Progressive.

headline: News Summary;THURSDAY, AUGUST 28, 1980
leadPara: International Strikes in Poland spread further as teams of workers from the strike headquarters in Gdansk sought new support in industrial centers around the country for their demands for independent labor unions and other changes. After leaders of the walkout and Government representatives had met in Gdansk, there were conflicting reports on whether progress had been made. (Page A1, Column 6.) Polish strikers have set up an enclave at a sprawling shipyard in Gdansk that is self-governing and is publishing a daily newspaper circulating around the country. The strike leaders have established an elaborate administrative apparatus providing for guards, couriers and groups collecting donations and supplying food. (A1:5.) An Ethiopian attack on Somalia was reported by the Somali radio, which said that the raiding force was supported by fighter-bombers. (A3:1.) Canada lost two major newspapers as two publishing chains continued to divide up the country's shrinking industry. The Ottawa Journal abruptly halted operations after 95 years, leaving the capital with only one English-language newspaper. In Winnipeg, The Tribune suspended publication after a costly circulation war with the city's only other newspaper. (A3:1-3.) French Navy tugs smashed a blockade by fishermen at the country's largest oil-tanker terminal at Fos outside Marseilles for the second time in 10 days, using water cannon and tear-gas grenades. The fishermen fought back, hurling rocks and bolts. (A3:4-6.) National A large bomb left by extortionists blew up in a Lake Tahoe casino as experts used a remote-control device in an effort to defuse it. Thousands of people had been evacuated from the gambling district in Stateline, Nev., and no injuries were reported. The bomb was wheeled into an office in a hotel casino Tuesday by two people who said they were delivering a photocopying machine. The bomb was accompanied by a letter demanding $3 million. (A1:3-4.) The North won an energy aid dispute in the House. A proposal to change the formula for distribution of $1.8 billion in low-income fuel assistance was defeated by a vote of 215 to 199. The debate focused on a plan to increase the Sun Belt's share of such aid at the expense of the Frost Belt. (A1:1.) An editor and his wife were indicted by a county grand jury in Georgia on charges of having tried to aid the escape of four convicted killers from the State Prison. The couple were accused of attempting unsuccessfully in June to send hacksaw blades to the inmates. Four of them escaped July 28 after sawing through prison bars. (A1:1.) Miami is prospering as a magnet for tourism, shopping, banking and commerce. The recent shocks of rioting by blacks in the Liberty City area and the tidal wave of Cuban refugees that made Miami a catchword for both despair and hope are still deeply felt but surprisingly difficult to see. The major change, according to many businessmen, politicians and civic leaders, is the image of the city. (A1:2-4.) Senator Mike Gravel was defeated in Alaska's Democratic primary by Clark Gruening, a lawyer, after a bitter campaign that focused on the sources of the Gravel campaign financing and on his inability to block a Senate bill barring development of millions of acres in the state. (A12:1-2.) Clarifying a remark by Ronald Reagan was undertaken by his staff after he declared that President Carter ''has created a severe depression.'' The chief economic adviser of the Republican Presidential nominee acknowledged that most economists believed the nation was in ''a very severe recession,'' not a depression. (B9:1-2.) A research agency is threatened with erosion of its long-cherished independence, in the view of many scientists. At issue is a bill nearing a vote in the House that would require the budget of the National Institutes of Health to be regularly reauthorized by Congress, which is required for most Government agencies, and for a yearly spending ceiling to be set by Congress. (D19:1-2.) The disclosure of a key arms advance stirred rising controversy. Members of a House panel, after hearing sworn testimony, charged that secret information on the development of a plane that is nearly undetectable by Soviet radar was leaked to a reporter so that the Pentagon could justify announcing the achievement. (A16:1-2.) Metropolitan A tentative accord in the PATH strike was reached after 11 weeks by negotiators for the railroad and the 177 striking carmen. The agreement will be submitted to a ratification vote by the union members tomorrow, and full service was expected to be restored for the morning rush Tuesday. Details of the accord were not disclosed. (A1:2.) Two views of Jacob K. Javits's health are portrayed in contrasting television campaign commercials. The Senator raised the issue when he disclosed last February that he had motor-neuron disease. It is a chronic condition that damages nerves, causes muscles to wither and is usually progressive. His doctors describe Senator Javits as ''vigorous'' and say they believe that he can serve another term. (A1:5-6.) An oil tax has had unexpected results in Connecticut. The original targets of the new 2 percent levy on the gross receipts of oil companies were their profits, but the burden is apparently falling mainly on homeowners and small fuel dealers and may soon be passed on to motorists too. (B1:4-6.) Business Digest, Page D1

headline: LABOR LEADER FEARS LOSS OF MORE NONDEFENSE JOBS IN STATE
leadPara: HAMDEN DESPITE the advent of Labor Day, John J. Driscoll is not in a holiday mood. ''I feel that we've been fortunate and to some extent insulated from the national recession,'' he said. ''But I doubt we can escape the brunt of it, and I'm afraid what its long-term effect will be on Connecticut manufacturing.'' As president of the Connecticut State Labor Council, the legislative and political voice for 175,000 active and retired workers affiliated with A.F.L.-C.I.O. unions, Mr. Driscoll is the state's chief spokesman for organized labor. In a recent two-hour interview at the council's headquarters, crammed into a house in this New Haven suburb, he blamed state tax policies and energy costs for the loss of high-paying manufacturing jobs, and assailed Federal trade policies and decisions by American ''transnational corporations'' to shift production to factories overseas.

headline: SPLIT OF U.S. CIRCUIT COURT IN SOUTH NEAR ENACTMENT AFTER LONG DEBATE
leadPara: Sixteen years after the idea was broached, a proposal to split the Deep South's Fifth Federal judicial circuit, where many of the nation's key civil rights cases evolved, appears headed for Congressional enactment. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, now with 26 judges hearing cases from six rapidly growing Southern states, is the nation's largest. The plan to divide the jurisdiction has had numerous ups and downs because of the role the court has played in the development of civil rights law.

headline: by Robert J. Gerberg
leadPara: In 1882, when Peter J. McGuire of the Knights of Labor suggested that the first Monday in September be declared a holiday ''in honor of labor,'' one's place in the working world was easily defined. If you belonged to ''labor,'' you worked a 12 to 15 hour day, without overtime, for wages and nothing more; if you belonged to ''management'' you owned - often by inheritance - a business. Businesses were smaller then and supervisors were more often part of labor than part of management. As we celebrate our 98th Labor Day, the roles of labor and management are not so clear-cut. In certain significant instances, they have almost become reversed. For example, today, when many workers are contractually protected against having to work excessive hours to keep their jobs, many executives at the same companies commonly labor 12 to 15 hours daily, six or seven days per week, just to hold their present positions. Since this is the era of the professional manager and the publicly-held corporation, today's executive does not own the business he helps manage. Consequently, today's manager is essentially a worker, a ''laborer'' - albeit a well-paid one who works in decent surroundings.

headline: THE G.O.P. IS RIGHT ON ABORTION
leadPara: Valentine INDIANAPOLIS - The landmark United States Supreme Court decision in 1973 in Roe v. Wade, which effectively legalized abortion, was supposed to have laid the issue to rest. It did not. That the abortion dilemma remains very much a controversial and divisive public concern is nowhere more plainly evident than in the Democratic and Republican platforms. The parties' planks on abortion are diametrically opposed. The Democrats affirm the Court's ruling as the law of the land, oppose any effort to overturn that decision by means of a constitutional amendment, and endorse a renewal by Congress of Federal funding of abortions for poor women.

headline: WORKERS IN EASTERN EUROPE TEST THE PARTY LINE
leadPara: Papa,'' a 10-year-old boy said to his father, an East European diplomat, ''why are the workers striking in Poland? Isn't Poland a socialist country?'' The father, relating the incident in Washington last week with visible distress, said he had to ponder this 64 zillion zloty question before he could assemble a Delphic response to the son: ''Socialists make mistakes, too ...and some Socialists make big mistakes.'' In the light of three weeks of widespread strikes in Poland and labor disturbances in other Soviet bloc countries in recent years, some Communists are wondering whether the venerable boast of erecting ''the dictatorship of the proletariat'' has grown hollow. Marxist-Leninist ideology has long held that strikes were not possible in Communist societies because ''workers cannot strike against their own interests.'' A philosophical dictionary published in East Berlin defines ''strike'' as something that happens only ''under capitalism.'' However, Communist countries have avoided expressly forbidding strikes, on the principle that ''what cannot be, will not be.'' Thus, as these countries told the United Nations last year, none has laws mentioning strikes.

headline: Senator Javits, Above All
leadPara: The main question in New York's Senate race is whether Jacob Javits deserves re-election to a fifth term. A national figure and asset to his state and party, he should be rejected only for compelling reasons. Republicans must answer the question in Tuesday's primary, while Democrats choose among four challengers. Yet even if, faithlessly, Republicans nominate Alfonse D'Amato, the presiding supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, Mr. Javits would still have the Liberal Party line in November. So the question of his fate will remain before the electorate.

headline: NO DAY OFF FOR REP. PEPPER AS HE MARKS 80th BIRTHDAT
leadPara: The Gray Panther of Capitol Hill danced a lively jig today as he celebrated his 80th birthday. ''I haven't got an ache or pain in the world,'' said Representative Claude D. Pepper, Democrat of Florida, the oldest member of the House. President Carter sent birthday greetings. House colleagues cheered him on the floor. His staff toasted him in his office, which was festooned with balloons, streamers and flowers. The House Rules Committee, on which he serves as ranking Democrat, gave him a party, too.

headline: Taxes; Plans to Ease Marriage Levy
abstract: Deborah Rankin article discusses tax on married couples vis-a-vis single persons and proposal by Pres Carter to ease marriage levy; chart on present tax and effect of Carter's proposal (M)

headline: Taxes;Plans to Ease Marriage Levy
leadPara: AS more and more women have entered the labor force, there has been growing pressure to lessen or eliminate the ''marriage penalty'' that taxes many working couples more severely than if both partners were single. Sensing a politically popular issue in this election year, Congressmen have been trying to outdo one another in devising solutions to the problem. President Carter's recent proposal to grant a limited deduction to working couples puts the official stamp of approval on the effort. Under the law, when one spouse does not work or earns less than 20 percent of total family income, the couple generally pays the lowest tax rates. However, when both spouses work and earn roughly the same salary, they pay the highest rates, while single people and heads of household pay rates somewhere in between. The marriage tax on working couples can be as much as 7.4 percent of their after-tax income.

headline: A 'MR. ONTARIO' IN THE SPOTLIGHT
leadPara: Watching William Grenville Davis on nationwide television during Canada's current crucial constitutional conference, it is hard for a casual observer to believe that the reserved silverhaired lawyer puffing his pipe could become passionate over anything, though he is reported to have uttered a mild oath when his small plane once narrowly missed a barn. However, many Canadians can become passionate over Mr. Davis, the Premier of Ontario. For he is the present symbol of the ''Ontario octopus,'' the powerful geographic headquarters of the economic and political interests that have run the rest of Canada like a colonial empire throughout the country's 113 year history. For starters, Ontario, which is eight times the size of New York State, has onethird of Canada's 23 million citizens, half the country's manufacturing, the de facto headquarters of the five most powerful national banks, the political capital of Ottawa and the economic, publishing, entertainment and cultural capital of Toronto.

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN SPEECH OUTLINING FIVE-YEAR ECONOMIC PROGRAM FORU.S.
leadPara: Following is a transcript of Ronald Reagan's speech before the International Business Council today: Almost two months ago, in accepting the Presidential nomination of my party, I spoke of the historically unique crisis facing the United States. At that time I said: ''Never before in our history have Americans been called upon to face three grave threats to our very existence, any one of which could destroy us. We face a disintegrating economy, a weakened defense and an energy policy based on the sharing of scarcity.''

headline: Union Chiefs Denounce Liberals Over Anderson
leadPara: The politically influential leaders of 12 major unions in New York denounced the Liberal Party's policy committee yesterday for endorsing Representative John B. Anderson for President. They said the action betrayed the progressive ideas for which the party had long stood. ''John Anderson is anti-labor and anti-liberal,'' said a statement by the union leaders, who support President Carter. ''The Liberal Party's action helped one candidate only - Ronald Reagan.''

headline: A WARNING ON INFLATION ISSUED
leadPara: The Committee for Economic Development, made up of a group of business and academic leaders, warned yesterday that in trying to deal with the recession the Government should not forget that the main long-range economic problem is still inflation and that the fight against it should not be relaxed. A statement issued by the committee, made up of 200 trustees who are generally chairmen of corporations and presidents of universities, said that ''the central aim of national economic policy should be a progressive year-by-year reduction in the underlying inflation rate - continuing after the recession has ended - until essential price stability is achieved.''

headline: Choices Made and Still to Come
leadPara: Whatever moved the voters in New York's primary, the symbolism of their verdict is plain. In nominating Elizabeth Holtzman and Alfonse D'Amato for the Senate, both Democrats and Republicans endorsed a new political generation that is impatient with the veneration, and moderation, of the old. Youth won out, as did ideological clarity. Costly television appeals could not save Bess Myerson and Jacob Javits. Neither could lofty endorsements by Mayor Koch and Senator Moynihan or by President Ford and Senator Goldwater. Miss Holtzman and Mr. D'Amato ran against distant ''interests'' and proved the value of troops on the ground; both had good organizations to rally their supporters. Miss Myerson was surely hurt by competition from John Lindsay and John Santucci. Senator Javits had to fight the suspicion that he is too old and ill to carry on.

headline: A RELUCTANT TRANSFER TO CARTER CAMP
leadPara: THE press must have asked me a hundred times during the four-day Democratic National Convention whether, as Senator Edward M. Kennedy's Connecticut campaign coordinator, I would back Jimmy Carter in the fall election. Repeatedly I told them that I would and then, as if shoving a thermometer under my tongue to measure the temperature of my commitment, they would ask again, ''Yes, but how hard will you work for Carter?'' How does one explain that after almost a year of working for Ted Kennedy, one does not easily transfer the fervor or the feeling. Of course I shall work for Jimmy Carter in this election campaign. I am a loyal Democrat; I have always supported the Democratic nominees; I believe the Democratic Party is incomparably better than the Republican, and I am appalled at the thought of Ronald Reagan in the White House. But although I shall support and work for Jimmy Carter, the pain I feel at not having Senator Kennedy at the helm is not easily relieved.

leadPara: The new six-man National Security Council, headed by Gen. Kenan Evren, the armed forces Chief of Staff, ordered tanks off the streets of the Turkish capital today and told ranking civil servants to take over the day-to-day running of their ministries. The council, whose members toppled Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel in an apparently bloodless coup yesterday, held meetings at military headquarters throughout the day seeking ways to solidify its grip on the nation of 45 million.

headline: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
leadPara: WHEN I was growing up on the Island, I knew a girl who had a pony. I have thought about her occasionally when I visited my parents' house in eastern Queens, where I was raised. (Talk about roots: My mother has lived in the same house for more than 50 years.) In many ways, our neighborhood has the same charm of 35 years ago: the quiet streets, the thick groves of trees, the private backyards giving no clue of being within a mile of the end of the subway line.

headline: MILWAUKEE
leadPara: WHATEVER is happening to the rest of the economy, this city almost always continues to prosper. Such has been the case in the recession of 1980. The area's durability is frequently attributed to such factors as its mix of industry and the fact that many businesses here are owned by people with a stake in the city. Some think the quality of the workers may account for much of Milwaukee's success. Executives say privately that they would sometimes like to lay workers off but fear they would never get their skilled people back.

headline: THEATER FEELS 'NECESSITY'S SHARP PINCH'
leadPara: STRATFORD IN its 25th anniversary year, the American Shakespeare Theater has won friends and alienated critics. The production of ''Richard III,'' the sole Shakespearean offering of a summer season that otherwise consisted of touring companies of ''Carousel,'' ''The Student Prince'' and ''Mame,'' was pounced upon and then slain by most reviewers. According to the theater's management, however, ''Richard III,'' which closed two weeks ago, ''broke even'' -a verdict that the managers say signals an economic turnaround for the octagonal building on the banks of the Housatonic and outweighs critical censure in determining its future.

headline: SEAFIRST BANK'S IMAGE PROBLEM
leadPara: On most days, William M. Jenkins, chairman of the Seattle-First National Bank, pilots his own boat from his home on Bainbridge Island to his office here in one of the city's tallest new skyscrapers. ''I've done it in all kinds of weather,'' said the athletic 61-year-old banker who has been at the helm of the Northwest's largest bank for 17 years. For most of those years, he has directed the bank on a smooth and profitable course, which has included a diversification program into mortgage banking, leasing and computer services. Assets of the Seafirst Corporation, the bank's parent, have grown in the last 10 years from $2.2 billion to $8.4 billion as of Aug. 1. In Washington State, the bank controls nearly 40 percent of the market and handles most of the correspondent banking for transactions between United States and Asian companies in the region.

headline: McGOVERN IN NEW BATTLE - FOR SURVIVAL
leadPara: He ran for President once. The television crews came around, then, and the police escorts and the cheering crowds. Then he lost. The scent of power vanished as fast as it had come. And now, eight years later, he was back home, walking the streets and shaking the hands and making the small talk, practically alone, a figure out of history trying to win one more chunk of the future.

headline: Lucey Says President Will Run Third in Election
leadPara: By United Press International Patrick J. Lucey, the former Governor of Wisconsin who is the independent Vice-Presidential candidate, predicted yesterday that President Carter would run third in November. Asked on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press'' who he thought would run second in November, he answered: ''My guess, frankly, is that, like 1912, the incumbent will run third.'' In 1912, Theodore Roosevelt left the Republican Party to run on the Progressive ''Bull Moose'' ticket, finishing finished second to the Democratic candidate, Woodrow Wilson. President William H. Taft ran third, with 23 percent of the vote.

headline: Taxes;  The Argument Over Tax Relief
leadPara: WASHINGTON THE Commerce Department's prediction last Friday that the gross national product would register a small gain for the September quarter appears to have extinguished any last hopes that Congress would pass an income tax relief bill in 1980. Even among junior Democrats who had been thought likely to lead a rump Ways and Means Committee movement for a bill, those hopes had been fading. As one such Democrat, Representative Thomas J. Downey of West Islip, L.I., puts it, ''The economy is coming out of this (recession) without a tax cut.''

headline: U.S. CALLS DOCUMENT ON AFRICA A FORGERY
leadPara: The White House asserted today that an unidentified group had sought to sow racial discord and complicate American relations with Africa by circulating in this country a forged United States document calling for American support for South Africa and surveillance of black leaders. The document, copies of which were distributed to reporters at a briefing, also calls for a policy of inhibiting ''coordinated activity of the black nationalist movement in Africa and the black movement in the United States.'' It suggests that American intelligence agencies monitor the activities of black American leaders and ''black African representatives, and collect sensitive information on those, especially at the U.N., who oppose U.S. policy toward South Africa.''

headline: Carlos Fuentes
leadPara: The evolving Central American political situation will soon pose the sharpest diplomatic test that the United States and Latin America have faced since the Cuban Revolution. A very long story of oppression and injustice imposed by a tiny group of oligarchs and army officers is coming to an end. The United States has the misfortune of being perceived as the principal backer of these corrupt regimes. In the 1930's, United States interventionism created the National Guard in Nicaragua and handed power to the Somoza family. In 1954, Washington set the Central Intelligence Agency on the mildly reformist Guatemalan regime of Col. Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, interrupting the hard-won democratic process and inaugurating a quarter-century of escalating violence.

headline: SPAIN'S REVAMPED CABINET WINS CONFIDENCE VOTE
leadPara: Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez's reshuffled minority Government won a vote of confidence tonight, gaining the support of Catalan and Andalusian regional parties. Mr. Suarez had called for the vote after making major changes in his center-right Cabinet last week, replacing among other ministers his Deputy Prime Minister for Economic Affairs and his Foreign Minister. The confidence vote, the first in Spain's young democracy, carried by 180 votes to 164.

headline: THE TURKS HAVE A WORD FOR IT - KEMALISM
leadPara: The ranking officers of the Turkish Army proudly gathered one day last week at the Ataturk Mausoleum, the vast monument of stairways, plazas and pillars in the Moderne-official mode of the 1930's that houses the body of the founder of modern Turkey. As they do each year, they placed a wreath on the gravesite of General Cemal Gursel, who led the military coup that took over the country in 1960. General Kenan Evren and the other leaders of the current coup were not present, however. They were meeting with the civil servants they had told to stay on, trying to learn how the government works.

headline: VARIETY OF MORTAGE PLANS OFFERED BY LENDERS GROWS
leadPara: Faced once again with rising interest rates and a shortage of deposits, lending institutions are starting to offer a wider variety of mortgages for the home buyer while at the same time turning to new programs and plans to attract funds. Since the current housing slump, attributable in part to Federal money policies beginning last October to curb inflation, savings banks and savings and loan associations have not been successful in attracting funds in sufficient amounts because the interest they could pay depositors was competitively unattractive. Consequently, mortgage loans from the thrift institutions have been sharply reduced.

headline: FEARS ON RISE ABOUT GROWING ROLE OF RELIGION IN ELECTION CAMPAIGNS
leadPara: In the Presidential debate last night, Ronald Reagan and Representative John B. Anderson were asked whether they believed that a President ''should be guided by organized religion'' on controversial issues, such as abortion. The answers were perhaps the most impassioned statements of the debate.. Mr. Reagan basically said yes and explained, ''I have thought for a long time that too many of our churches have been too reluctant to speak up in behalf of what they believe is proper in government.''

headline: CONGRESSIONAL BLACK CAUCUS GATHERS FOR SESSION MARKING 10 YEARS OFGROWTH
leadPara: The Congressional Black Caucus begins its tenth annual legislative weekend in Washington tomorrow after a decade in which it has moved from uncertainty about its mission to a balance between its roles as a legislative body and a national leadership group for black Americans, according to those in political circles. The caucus has grown steadily in stature, numbers and sophistication, in the view of many analysts. The bipartisan group of 15 Democrats and one Republican includes all the black members of the House. It was the House's first formal organization based on ethnic or economic or regional bonds and continues to be one of the most active.

LANE BRYANT'S CANADIAN SUITOR
leadPara: James Kay, the architect of a business empire that includes 736 clothing stores, two race tracks, a fast-food chain and investments in oil and gas, mining and real estate, remains an enigma to most Canadians. And the recent interest shown by the 58-year-old executive in Lane Bryant Inc., the New York-based clothing chain, has piqued some Americans' curiosity about him as well. This summer, the Hatleigh Corporation of Toronto, an investment holding company of which Mr. Kay is chairman, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it might seek control of Lane Bryant, which operates in 31 states and reported sales of $381.2 million last year. Hatleigh now owns 12 percent of Lane Bryant. Lane Bryant has indicated that it is opposed to a takeover.

headline: UPAVON, England
leadPara: TEN years ago, Barry Wookey stopped using chemical fertilizers on a small portion of his 1,600-acre wheat farm southwest of London. He'd read Rachel Carson's ''Silent Spring,'' and though his father and grandfather before him had advocated progressive farming, Mr. Wookey had his doubts about what chemicals were doing to the land and the food. Then, Mr. Wookey was branded as a crank by neighboring farmers and the minister of agriculture. But no more. Today, with the price of chemical fertilizers and insecticides rising by the season, and with increasing concern for food safety and the environment, Mr. Wookey and his fellow organic farmers around the world are more than curiosities.

headline: PERSONAL HEALTH
leadPara: DOWAGER'S hump,'' hip fractures, shortened stature - these common hallmarks of late-middle and old age are the result of an even more common disorder, osteoporosis, a progressive loss and weakening of bone. Though it has long been regarded as an inevitable and irremediable consequence of aging, especially in women past menopause, recent studies suggest that osteoporosis may be largely preventable and partly treatable. The protein- and mineral-rich foods you eat and the amount of exercise you get may make the difference between lifelong healthy bones and progressive skeletal deterioration.

headline: NEW TERRITORY FOR THE TALKING HEADS
leadPara: With the release this week of their fourth album, ''Remain in Light,'' the Talking Heads confirm their position as America's most venturesome rock band. But they do so in a way that might at first seem unexpected. Talking Heads started out five years ago as a trio of minimalist art-rockers from the Rhode Island School of Design - David Byrne, the bandleader, songwriter, singer and guiarist; Tina Weymouth, the bass player, and Chris Frantz, the drummer. Before the release of their first album, they had added Jerry Harrison, a Harvard man who had played with Jonathan Richman and the Modern Lovers, a pioneering minimalist art-rock band from Boston. And by the second and third albums, they had for all practical purposes added a fifth member for their work in the recording studio: Brian Eno, the erstwhile British progressive-rock wizard.

headline: CARTER'S FISCAL TWIST
leadPara: WASHINGTON F ROM the beginning, fiscal policy - spending and taxation - has been a minefield of surprises and setbacks for the Carter Administration. Starting with the President's stunning withdrawal in 1977 of his proposal for a $50 tax rebate (a turnaround that left some Cabinet officers out on a limb) and continuing to his 1980 budget juggling, it has seemed that the Carter Administration could not decide what it wanted to do on the fiscal front. Mr. Carter's critics have charged that he was inconsistent and that he lacked a clear economic philosophy. Others might say that the Administration was whipsawed by swiftly changing economic forces, particularly the 1979-80 explosion of oil prices.

headline: by Fernando Valdivia
leadPara: Since 1977, a well-meaning United States foreign policy has sought the return of democracy in Bolivia, where the military has ruled from 1964 to 1979. This effort was thwarted by the military coup on July 17 that prevented President-elect Hernan Siles Suazo from taking office. Protesting the coup, Washington suspended foreign aid and recalled its ambassador. Since 1943, the United States has sometimes viewed Bolivia's progressive social movements as Communist, a perception that has distorted policy making. It has assumed that the Communist Parties (Kremlin- and Peking-oriented) are well-organized and have wide popular support. Yet Ernesto ''Che'' Guevara's 1967 expedition aimed at overthrowing the Government failed because it received scant support from both parties, for they were, and remain, an intellectual, elite minority distant from the working classes. Further, the 1952 nationalization of the tin mines and the 1953 agrarian reform largely pre-empted Guevara's appeal for social justice.

headline: WELCOME TO DOEVILLE
leadPara: Despite Edward M. Kennedy's efforts, American liberalism is emerging from the 1980 election season in a terminal state. The number of politicians who campaign on platforms for oncehallowed liberal goals such as school busing or national health insurance would scarcely add up to a a rump chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union. Yet liberalism's collapse has not moved the bulk of the population to the right, whatever the hopes of Republican strategists. Few people buy the notion that our energy problems will be solved by ''turning loose'' the oil companies. None but the most zealous corporate and right-wing ideologues think that our nation's cities could be rebuilt and our unemployed youth gainfully employed if only trade unions were eviscerated, environmental and consumer safeguards rolled back, and women returned to the kitchen. An enormous vacuum exists in American politics. Public-opinion polls chronicle declining confidence in big government and big business. What has yet to be grasped is the counterweight to both that is forming now: an active, informed citizenry itself. If one looks under the rhetoric about the the ''me decade'' and the meanness supposedly poisoning the American psyche, evidence of a new spirit of civic idealism and community self-help can be found everywhere.

leadPara: MINNEAPOLIS--Despite Edward M. Kennedy's efforts, American liberalism is emerging from the 1980 election season in a terminal state.

headline: World travels add dimension to Police album
leadPara: LAST year, the British rock group Police achieved a commercial breakthrough in America with its second album, ''Reggatta de Blanc'' (A & M). Songs like ''Message in a Bottle,'' ''Walking on the Moon'' and ''The Bed's Too Big Without You'' became FM radio favorites and the album sold well. Having penetrated the lucrative American market, most British groups would have devoted several months to intensive touring and promotional activities in the United States. Instead, Miles Copeland, the Police's unconventional manager, arranged a world tour that found the band playing in Bombay and other cities where live rock has rarely been heard. The tour may not have consolidated the group's position in America, but it does seem to have provided food for thought. The third Police album, ''Zenyatta Mondatta,'' released earlier this week, isn't a radical departure from the distinctive style developed on the first two LP's, but the band's emphasis has shifted. A reggae influence pervaded the Police's earlier music, and their lyrics tended to focus on personal concerns. Now reggae is simply one of a number of international colorings that lend variety to the group's sound and a number of new songs, especially those written by Sting, the bassist and lead vocalist, reflect the impact of travel in alien cultures.

headline: A NEW PHASE FOR CALIFORNIA COASTAL PLAN
leadPara: Eight years ago the people of California, dismayed at the progressive despoliation of their 1,000-mile shoreline, wrested control of coastal development from 53 communities and 15 counties. Now that jurisdiction is being returned to the localities, but with enough strings attached to weave what is hoped will be a protective blanket for the coastline's future. Plying the shuttle back and forth has been the California Coastal Commission. Established in 1972 amid the coastal conservation uproar, it is the state's ultimate authority in coastal matters, the court of last appeal from the decisions of its six regional commissions. It represents an epochal venture in land-use control that may serve as a model for 29 other coastal and Great Lakes states and, perhaps, for those who would regulate inland areas. For the moment, however, the 12-citizen board continues holding its own as the regulatory model for the people who put it there.

headline: A LONG CAREER,BUT STILL A FRESH EYE
leadPara: PORT WASHINGTON IN an age that seems to applaud change and often sees the meteoric rise and equally rapid decline of creative talents, it is sobering to reflect on a career such as that of Isabel Bishop. She is one of the few outstanding painters of her generation who has developed in the figurative tradition without being stifled by it, and whose progressive examination of the human form has evolved with a deliberateness worthy of the old masters whom she has studied so closely. The small survey of her paintings, drawings and prints currently on view at the Port Washington Library gives some idea of the singlemindedness with which she has pursued her goal of expressing mobility and vitality in an essentially static medium. It also shows how her approach to that problem has changed during her long career.
