headline: STRUGGLE SPLITS ISLAMIC AND ARAB LOYALTIES
leadPara: existing basic division in the Middle East between pan-Arabism and pan-Islamism. It has divided and further crippled the ''progressive'' left within the Arab world. It has intensified personal power struggles between Arab leaders unrelated to ideology or religion. It has drawn the United States and the Soviet Union more deeply and directly into the area. It has been a blow for the Palestinians, and it has given Israel a respite by moving the Israeli-Palestinian issue off center stage. Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi President, has justified his invasion of Iran as a war to defend the Arab nation and Arab territory from an imperialist non-Arab intruder. Jordan's King Hussein, the only Arab leader to commit himself actively and publicly on Iraq's side, has also done so in the name of Arab nationalism and solidarity. The Iranians, he told the British Broadcasting Corporation, have a long history of ''infringements'' against the Arabs in the Persian Gulf. He also said the Arabs must support Iraq because it is the only country that gives them ''strategic depth'' against Israel now that the Egyptians have taken themselves out of the Arab battle line.

headline: Excerpts From the President's Remarks About Condition of Nation's Economy; Strategy on Inflation Reagan Proposals Assailed Policy on Creating Jobs
leadPara: Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Carter's remarks on the economy at the National Press Club yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM THE PRESIDENT'S REMARKS ABOUT CONDITION OF NATION'S  ECONOMY
leadPara: Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Carter's remarks on the economy at the National Press Club yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News. This has been a very difficult and painful period of high inflation and unemployment, particularly painful to some Americans who have, in their own family, suffered most. Fortunately our nation has been able to withstand this blow. The economic outlook has now brightened. We see the beginnings of recovery. We see a reduction in inflation, an increase in the number of jobs, a decline in the unemployment rate.

leadPara: NEW YORK is a string-band festival this weekend, and that is no exaggeration. Doug Tuchman's winter bluegrass and old-time countrymusic series begins tonight at New York University's Loeb Student Center on Washington Square South with a program called the First Big Apple String Band Festival. headline: Mr. Javits's Risk - and Opportunity
leadPara: We still think Jacob Javits is the best, by far, of the three candidates running for the Senate in New York. But we note with pain, six days before election, that his long-shot struggle to recover from defeat in the Republican primary has run out of steam. Many of the Senator's lifelong supporters, including members of his staff, have lost heart and Mr. Javits stands to run a poor third. If he persists, he risks drawing enough liberal and moderate votes from Elizabeth Holtzman to assure the election of the least desirable candidate, Alfonse D'Amato. The Senator knows the likely consequences for New York. When moderates last split their Senate votes - between Charles Goodell and Richard Ottinger in 1970 - the result was the election, by a slender plurality, of the conservative James Buckley. And for six years, Mr. Buckley nullified Mr. Javits's progressive votes in the Senate.

headline: Something Decent On The Wane
leadPara: As he spoke to a group of senior citizens the other morning at the Oracle Villa Apartments, Mo Udall pointed to a sere brown ridge rising north of this sprawling city. One of the last surviving herds of bighorn sheep live in those hills, he said, and ''they'll be there for your grandchildren to see'' - because as chairman of the House Interior Committee, he'd been able to include the ridge in the national wilderness system. Because of that same powerful position, he suggested, he would be able to help Tucson prepare ''an orderly growth pattern'' for the ''close to a million people'' who'd be living there before the century was out (the city's population is only half that now).

headline: HOW TO SURVIVE ON THE RAILS
leadPara: WASHINGTON T HERE is a certain air of ''The Little Engine That Could'' about the clattering train edging along the Eastern Shore of Maryland. It's slow, doing about 10 or 15 miles an hour, and only runs on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays. The engineer is a former computer supervisor and the other half of the crew runs his own general store on days off. This is the Maryland & Delaware Railroad, run by an ex-systems analyst from Philadelphia who loves trains. But the Maryland & Delaware, like scores of short-line railways across the nation, is proving itself a stubborn survivor of the shake-out in the rail industry that has been brought on by rapidly rising costs - especially for labor.

headline: WHAT'S ALLOWED ON TV--PRESSURES FOR CHANGE ARE MOUNTING
leadPara: Among the many decisions to be made this election day, one in particular will not be made at the polls. It will be made by television viewers in their homes in New York, Los Angeles and a dozen other cities where the choice involves bypassing the election-night banter of Messrs. Cronkite, Chancellor and Reynolds, in favor of watching the Academy Award-winning Vietnam War drama, ''The Deer Hunter.'' If enough viewers cast their ''vote'' for ''The Deer Hunter'' - which its New York City outlet, WOR-TV/Channel 9, warns ''contains dramatic subject matter and dialogue suitable only for mature audiences'' - it could have major implications for the future of television. The issue to be decided - or at least illuminated - is how far television may go in the showing of sex and violence. All three conventional broadcast networks - CBS, NBC and ABC - have rejected ''The Deer Hunter'' as too violent for television, while all the pay-cable networks - including Home Box Office and Showtime - as well as several local broadcast stations, including WOR-TV, deemed it acceptable. These differing standards raise important questions: Are some conventional broadcasters significantly liberalizing their views toward so-called adult material? If so, does the trend reflect a changing society or is it more the result of competitive pressure from cable and other forms of home video? Furthermore, as increased attention is focused on standards of taste and discretion, what will come of television's - especially network television's - procedures for self-censorship?

headline: One Right, Two Lefts

headline: One Right, Two Lefts
leadPara: Yet again, for New York's moderates and liberals, the political lesson should be obvious. Together, they continue to hold the balance of power in the state, even when some hostile winds are howling from across the Hudson. But when they sponsor rival candidates in a general election against conservatives, they split the vote and get blown away. There is no need to torture the numbers to prove the point; the might-have-beens in any election are not always demonstrable with arithmetic. But when third-party candidates like John Anderson and Jacob Javits gather even a modest 7 and 11 percent of the vote on a Liberal Party line, they obviously facilitate the election of candidates who stand far to the right of them and the electorate. Thus aided, Ronald Reagan took New York from Jimmy Carter by 3 points, 47-44. Even more clearly aided, Alfonse D'Amato defeated Elizabeth Holtzman for the Senate seat by a mere one percentage point, 45-44.

headline: THE TIDAL WAVE; by Anthony Lewis
leadPara: The Senate results make the point even more compellingly than Ronald Reagan's electoral vote landslide: What happened in the 1980 election reflected a profound and general turn to conservatism in this country. Particular issues this year worked to arouse conservative feelings. Abroad, there was the sense of American impotence, symbolized by the hostages in Iran. At home there was economic frustration, especially over the inflation.

headline: News Analysis
leadPara: The 1980 election has given the Republicans more than the White House and a startling increase in other offices from state capitals to the Capitol. It has given Republicans, especially conservative Republicans, an unaccustomed opportunity to carry out their ideas of how to run the country, a chance that was not so clear after some other Presidential elections in which they won the White House without making significant gains in Congress. Although a slim majority in the Senate and a deficit of about 50 seats in the House of Representatives is hardly the kind of dominance that the Democrats attained after the Lyndon B. Johnson landslide of 1964, it does offer the chance to govern.

headline: PATRONAGE, YES, PLUS...
leadPara: Some voters have ignored Presidential elections for many years. They believe that the noble goals stated by candidates never get translated into action because people in ''the system'' will do as they please regardless of the person in the White House. They are probably just as cynical about chief executives of state, county, and local governments and the systems they control. The reality of the patronage system takes over once the election excitement dies down, as newly elected candidates reward their faithful followers with jobs in government.

headline: ANTI-REAGAN PROTESTS CONTINUE FOR 3D DAY ON CALIFORNIA CAMPUS
leadPara: A group of radical organizations held a third day of protests against Ronald Reagan's election as President today but failed in an attempt to confront the administration of the Berkeley campus of the University of California. The group held anti-Reagan rallies on the campus Tuesday night and yesterday. Yesterday's protest turned into a march on California Hall, where 54 demonstrators were arrested last night in a corridor outside Chancellor Ira Michael Heyman's offices. Thirty-three were students, according to the authorities. Most of those arrested were charged with misdemeanor trespassing and 10 were also charged with resisting arrest. All were released without bail.

headline: Radio; Music Talk Events/Sports
BASEBALL: THE ALTERNATIVE TO RADIO
leadPara: To the Sports Editor: Mark Harris (''Recalling the Joy of Watching Baseball on the Radio,'' The New York Times, Oct. 12) brought nostalgic memories back to me. How well I remember when we kids would take turns running three blocks to newsstands under the shadows of the Park Row el near the entrance to Brooklyn Bridge to take a quick squint at the front pages of The Evening Sun, The Evening World or The Evening Telegram. There we would see the latest running baseball scores of our favorite teams midst the yapping of the newsstand owner ''Get outta here you bums!'' Radios were a luxury then. Very few of us had them at home. But we had one big luxury in those days. We actually thought we ''saw'' a baseball game, and they were World Series games, simulated on a large ''game'' board, about three stories high and 10 or so windows wide, against the side of the old New York Sun building at Chambers Street and Broadway facing City Hall.

headline: CLOUDS GATHER OVER NEW YORK RACING
leadPara: N OW is the time for all good horses to leave their stables in Ozone Park, Queens, or Elmont, L.I., and head south or west for the sunnier, richer racing climes of Florida and California. The Remsen Stakes for 2-year-olds today at Aqueduct is the last local race of national consequence until next April's Wood Memorial. For at least a generation, the months in New York between the Belmont Stakes in June and the Jockey Club Gold Cup in October have been the heart of the American racing calendar. Out-of-town horsemen dream of having a runner good enough to race at Belmont or Saratoga, and it is unusual for a horse to be voted a national championship without winning a major stake at Belmont in the fall.

headline: THE N.B.A. DRAFT BRINGS A WARM GLOW TO UTAH AND SAN DIEGO
leadPara: SALT LAKE CITY IT was the night before the Utah Jazz played an exhibition game against the Indiana Pacers in Louisville in late September and Darrell Griffith, Utah's No. 2 selection in last June's college draft, was still unsigned. But the contract negotiations were almost completed, and Griffith was sure this night, Sept. 26, would be his last as an amateur. It was close to 1 A.M. when he unlocked the gymnasium on the campus of the University of Louisville, his alma mater. Once inside, he zipped up and down the court - weaving and faking against imaginary defenders and driving in for the dunks that had earned him the nickname of ''Dr. Dunkenstein.'' His solitary workout lasted two hours.

The recount begins tomorrow. Both candidates have been predicting victory.

headline: Baseball: The Alternatives to Radio
MEASURING LIFE IN LUNCHTIMES
leadPara: LUNCHTIME is a very important part of my life. J. Alfred Prufrock may have measured out his life with coffee spoons, but mine can be measured in lunches -lunches eaten, lunches skipped, lunches sneaked and lunches only dreamed of. As a matter of fact, the sites, companions and styles of my progressive lunchtimes pretty well characterize the life situations in which I have found myself. My first recollections of lunchtimes are of those spent as the break in my elementary-school days. No doubt I had eaten lunches before I was 5, but those meals apparently did not have the same significance. I grew up in an old Westchester area where children all walked to their neighborhood schools and went home to Mom at lunch. The policeman at the one busy corner blew his whistle to stop traffic, and I remember watching this ritual with great yearning when I was still too young to join even the kindergarteners.

headline: IT COULDN'T HAPPEN THERE
leadPara: THE GREAT REBELLION Mexico, 1905-1924. By Ramon Eduardo Ruiz. 530 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $24.95.TAMERICA'S other Gulf crisis began 70 years ago this autumn when the unimaginable happened in Mexico. For a third of a century, Mexico had known a single ruler, Porfirio Diaz, a figure much admired in the United States. His twin gods were Order and Progress. Their handmaid was the foreign investor. Under his stern but paternal guidance, everyone agreed, a primitive country had begun the arduous climb into the modern era. In retrospect, the Mexican Revolution in many ways anticipated the recent history of Iran, with Diaz playing the part of a Hispanic Pahlevi. After seeing Diaz and touring his works, the steel magnate Andrew Carnegie remarked, ''In every corner of the Republic reigned prosperity and peace.'' According to Mexico's leading newspaper, a revolution was ''impossible.'' Perhaps the flavor is best conveyed by this passage, which I prize, from a 1910 guidebook to Mexico written by T. Philip Terry:

headline: THE PRINCE, YUGOSLAV-STYLE
leadPara: TITO The Story From Inside. By Milovan Djilas. Translated by Vasilije Kojic and Richard Hayes. 185 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $9.95. THERE was a kind of father-son relationship between Josip Broz Tito and Milovan Djilas that began when they met in the Yugoslav Communist underground in 1937. It continued through the horrors of the Partisan war, in which Tito was commander in chief and Djilas one of his closest aides, and beyond to victory - first the liberation of Yugoslavia from German occupation in 1945 and then, in 1948, the independence of the country from Soviet domination. But the bond that linked the two men was forever altered in 1954 when Djilas boldly called on Tito, 20 years his senior, to open the way for more democracy in Yugoslavia. From then on their relationship was lovehate at one level and u nrequited love at another.

headline: A SOVIET CHALLENGE'
leadPara: The question that exercises the minds of many Asian and third-world leaders is: ''Who will fill the vacant role of world leadership?'' The absence of such a leadership today lies at the root of contemporary international anarchy. After 30 years of United States leadership, we increasingly ask ourselves as we watch this great country stagger under this load: ''Will the United States opt out of the contest for world leadership?'' If it does, then the mantle of world leadership must fall, through default, on the Soviet Union, which does not flinch before the prospect of world leadership.

headline: HOW THE MIND AFFECTS OUR HEALTH
leadPara: By Laurence Cherry hey were strangers to each other, but the six men were alike in striking ways. Middle-aged and middle-class, each had, only a short time before, watched his wife succumb after a lingering, doomed battle with breast cancer. And as their wives were approaching death, each of the men had volunteered to become a subject in a study conducted at New York's Mount Sinai Medical Center to determine the physiological effects of bereavement. The results were dramatic. ''On all our tests,'' says Dr. Marvin Stein, chairman of the department of psychiatry at Mount Sinai, ''the men showed marked changes in their lymph cells, which help guard against disease.'' In other words, their bodies were apparently expressing grief on a very basic level. Their wives' illness had put them at greater risk to developing some kind of illness themselves.

headline: by David H. Berg
leadPara: On the first day of his Presidency, Jimmy Carter issued his promised pardon for civilian Vietnam War resistors, a document I had drafted. That evening, his pollster Pat Caddell, his media adviser Jerry Rafshoon, and I drove away from the west wing of the White House. We spoke of the lingering division in the country over Vietnam, between black and white, and even between North and South. Rafshoon sat with his hands in his trench-coat pockets, and as heat thawed the car he spoke enthusiastically of the new President: ''He can be a great healer. He's Southern. He's progressive. And he attracts great people.'' We thought Mr. Carter was an idealist at the center of a group of pragmatists. Yet he was to abandon his litany of seemingly highminded campaign promises at the first sign of resistance. All too soon, it became clear that he believed deeply in very little and passionately about nothing at all - except in getting elected.

headline: KEY REAGAN ADVISER URGES PROMPT CUTS IN FEDERAL SPENDING
leadPara: Caspar W. Weinberger, a senior economic adviser to President-elect Ronald Reagan, called today for prompt and ''severe'' reductions in Federal spending as new indications emerged that there was disagreement within Mr. Reagan's economic team over how large the cuts should be and how fast they should be made. Mr. Weinberger, who was a director of the Office of Management and Budget and Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the Nixon Administration and who is chairman of Mr. Reagan's Economic Policy Coordinating Committee, said he believed that Mr. Reagan still favored budget cuts that would limit Government spending to $620 billion or less in the fiscal year 1981.

headline: RADIO TRIES TO FILL ITS JAZZ VOID
leadPara: Three noncommercial radio stations are trying to take up the slack caused by the loss of the city's only all-jazz commercial radio station, WRVR, which converted to all-country music two months ago. However, even though the stations are offering more hours of jazz, the void created by the loss of WRVR cannot entirely be filled for concert promoters, jazz clubs, record companies, record producers and retail record stores. Among the stations attempting to fill the gap is WBGO-FM, Newark, which on Sept. 9 began broadcasting 18 hours of jazz a day. Previously it had offered 12 hours of jazz. However, WBGO, a National Public Radio station, has essentially a weak signal and does not reach all corners of New York City.

headline: MUSIC IS LIVING IN A LOFT ON 10TH AVE.
leadPara: Soundscape, the music-performance loft at 500 West 52d Street, near 10th Avenue, is alive with music most nights. What kind of music depends on which night. Tonight and tomorrow night, five of the leading lights of the European jazz avant-garde will be performing there. Tuesdays are Afro-Cuban nights and feature musicians who left Cuba in the most recent wave of immigration, as well as New York-bred musicians who play intraditional Afro-Cuban styles. Dec. 6, the poet Amiri Baraka will be reading new poems with jazz accompaniment by David Murray and Steve McCall. Verna Gillis, the academically trained ethnomusicologist who is Soundscape's founder and director, can be seen there whenever there's music. She's a large woman with a surfeit of contagious enthusiasm, who has recorded folk and ethnic music in Africa, Latin America and the Caribbean, but who now finds all the musical stimulation she needs in New York City.

headline: INDIAN SPEAKS FOR THE BLACKS IN SOUTH AFRICA
leadPara: In his own estimate, Pat Poovalingam is a man who has always expressed himself freely on issues without being inhibited by political fashions or parties. His critics dismiss him as a gadfly with a fondness for the sound of his own voice. Now, operating from a power base that is sc arcely as big as his ownhousehold in a well-to-do Indian suburb here, the 57-year-old lawyer finds that he has managed to make his voice h eard, at least faintly, throughout South Africa. He did it by laying down an ultimatum to the Government of Prime Minister P.W. Botha o n the touchiest, most important issue it faces: political rights fo r blacks.

headline: ZULU LEADER FACING A CHALLENGE AS VOICE OF SOUTH AFRICAN BLACKS
leadPara: Of the limited number of black voices that can be heard in South Africa, not one carries further among whites as well as blacks than that of Chief Gatsha Buthelezi, who, as leader of the Zulu ''homeland'' or ''national state,'' works within a system he has consistently denounced as oppressive. Operating from his tiny capital here on a parched, unpromising plain - which boasts what is said to be the world's smallest Holiday Inn, on the site of the battlefield where British forces finally broke Zulu power in 1879 - Chief Buthelezi has managed to build by far the largest black political organization in the country.

headline: SEPARATISM GROWS IN WESTERN CANADA
leadPara: Every few nights in the booming cities and towns of oil-rich Alberta, citizens are turning out by the thousands to cheer the idea that Canada's four western provinces ought to separate and be independent The sudden upsurge in the west of a sentiment previously prominent only in French-speaking Quebec is the most extreme expression of what Premier Peter Lougheed is calling Alberta's ''anger and frustration'' with policies dictated by the federal Government in Ottawa. In turn Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who started moves for a new Canadian constitution and a national energy policy, has called the west hysterical.

headline: GIGO and the Budget
leadPara: Herbert Stein, the University of Virginia economist who played a leading role in the Nixon and Ford Administrations, has usefully reminded Ronald Reagan and his economic planners of that dangerous phenomenon that the computer wizards call GIGO - ''garbage in, garbage out.'' Not that Mr. Stein accused the Reagan men of basing their economic plans on garbage; rather, in an article in The Wall Street Journal, he reminded them - and all the rest of us -that there's nothing hard and fast about economic projections. Like anything else that comes out of a computer, or the human brain, they're only as good as the assumptions on which they rest (all too often uneasily).

headline: Ruling Party Wins Election In Bermuda but Lead Is Cut
leadPara: The largest turnout of voters in Bermuda's history has returned the United Bermuda Party to power, but with a much reduced majority. The returns from yesterday's voting showed that the party's majority in the 40-seat House of Assembly had been reduced by six. The mainly white United Bermuda Party won 22 seats, while the opposition Progressive Labor Party, supported mainly by blacks, won 18. Before the election was called in October, the United Bermuda Party held 25 seats and the Progressive Labor Party 14, and there was one independent member.

headline: by Gregory D. Squires
leadPara: If liberalism is dead, rigor mortis has set in on the civil rights movement. Locked into a 1960's ideology inadequate for today, civil rights organizations are losing support from all sides of the political spectrum. Plant closings, corporate relocations, and capital mobility frame the context in which the dynamics of racism must be understood, and civil rights groups' failure to recognize the discriminatory implications of these developments typifies the blinders they wear. A recent study by the Illinois advisory commiteee to the United States Civil Rights Commission found that racial minorities suffer most from shutdowns and relocations. Minorities are concentrated in geographic locations, industries, and occupations hardest hit by capital mobility, and in some cases racial considerations have been a factor in relocations. For example, in Illinois companies moving from central cities to suburbs in the late 70's, employment of blacks dropped by almost

The majority of El Salvador's 4.5 million people have long staggered under a rigid class structure and distorted income distribution. Before some reforms this year, the top 5 percent of the population received 38 percent of the income; less than 2 percent owned more than half the valuable agricultural land.

headline: THE DEMOCRATS' FUTURE
leadPara: Jr. WASHINGT ON - If the Democrats are to resurrect themselves, like a phoenix, from the ashes of the 1980 election, they must face two harsh realities: The fire has been smoldering for some time, and the Democrats themselves not only started it, they've been fanning the flames for at least a decade. Ronald Reagan's victory is no freak electoral accident. Both Hubert H. Humphrey and George McGovern lost to Richard M. Nixon. In 1976, Jimmy Carter ran as a candidate outside the national Democratic Party. He won in large part by campaigning against both major political parties, with a promise to fumigate the stench of Watergate corruption and pervasive, senseless bureaucracy.

headline: WRONG WEAPON TO FIGHT INFLATION
leadPara: To the Editor: Raising interest rates as a means of fighting inflation is probably the most counterproductive policy that can be devised. As those rates climb, the higher cost of money are incorporated into the prices of virtually all goods and services. Simultaneously, the increases in the debt burden of government that arise from higher interest costs put enormous upward pressures on wages and other incomes as the progressive income tax structure diverts ever-larger shares of pre-tax income into taxes and thereby reduces discretionary income.

leadPara: Slightly more than a year after dissidents occupied the Grand Mosque in Mecca, the incident continues to influence the pace at which Saudi leaders bring modern benefits to a long-isolated nation. At the same time, according to interviews with senior Government and foreign officials here, reverberations from the occupation of the mosque, one of the holiest sites of Islam, by a group upset at modernization have not resulted in a major switch from the firm emphasis on economic development and the acceptance of resulting social change.

headline: ROCK SPOTS MORE PLENTIFUL AND FANCIER
leadPara: NEW YORK CITY is rock-and-roll heaven this weekend, and that's a curious state of affairs. World famous rock groups are finding it difficult to fill stadiums, record companies are complaining of rising costs and sagging sales figures, but the city is supporting more rock-and-roll clubs than ever before and new ones are opening with some frequency. Apparently, a growing number of rock-and-roll fans would rather go to a club, where they can dance to the music, buy drinks, feel closer to the performers and socialize with their friends, than pay up to twice as much money for a ticket to a concert by a supergroup. The clubs are getting fancier, too. A year ago, the ''in'' spots were mostly dark and functional; one went for the music and the cameraderie, not to admire the decor. But 1980 saw the opening of the Ritz, a roomy Art Deco palace on East 11th Street; Howard Stein's Rock Lounge, another well appointed new club at 285 West Broadway, and the resuscitated Peppermint Lounge, 128 West 45th Street. This weekend the cavernous Rock City, 157 Hudson Street, two blocks below Canal Street, opens its door for the first time. And the clubs that started it all -CBGB, Max's Kansas City, Hurrah, and the rest - are holding their own.

headline: PAMAMANIAN DOCTOR LISTENS FOR ANOTHER CALL TO ARMS
leadPara: Wearing the shorts he slipped on after a siesta, but already neatly shaven in preparation for a night on the town, Hugo Spadafora stood on the terrace of his duplex apartment overlooking the entrance to the Panama Canal and sipped a medicinal potion of apple vinegar, honey and water. ''I know that I'm something of a romantic, but I'm also very pragmatic,'' the tall green-eyed Panamanian said. ''Revolutions are coming to Latin America through historical imperative. Either you participate or you're a failed revolutionary. And I'm participating.''

headline: IN POP, IT WAS THE CONSERVATIVES VS. THE PROGRESSIVES
leadPara: Pop music can't be separated from the culture it reflects and, at its best, challenges. Nineteen-eighty was a year of economic retrenchment, of sweeping electoral victories for conservative politicians, of escapism at the movies and sullen muttering in the streets, and pop reflected all these things. There was a definite drift to the right. Middle-of-the-road pop (Kenny Rogers, Barbra Streisand) topped the albums and singles charts. Hordes of former disco fans traded in their dancing shoes for cowboy boots, and black sweet-harmony groups like Ray, Goodman and Brown enjoyed renewed popularity. At the same time, more progressive music was on the march. Rock's new wave may have splintered into several disparate and sometimes hostile camps, but the Clash, the Police and other new wave artists finally justified their fans' faith in them by making it big commercially. The music's more daring experimenters, from the venerable Captain Beefheart to the younger Talking Heads and Public Image Ltd., produced new work that even their fans found unexpectedly provocative. And while disco all but collapsed as a movement, the long anticipated alliance between black American disco and funk, new wave rock, and Jamaican reggae and other Third World pop began to seem not just possible but inevitable.

headline: RECOVERING WOMEN'S PAST
leadPara: WOMEN OF THE REPUBLIC Intellect and Ideology in Revolutionary America. By Linda K. Kerber. Illustrated. 304 pp. Chapel Hill, N.C.: Published for the Instituute of Early American History and Culture. The University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $19.50. Paper, $9. LET us admit at the outset that the history of the American Revolution can be told without so much as mentioning a woman, and - except for an occasional reference to Abigail Adams or Mercy Otis Warren - it generally is. The Revolution was a political event, and politics had no place in the traditional ''woman's sphere.'' Women remained at home, locked in a round of tasks so enduring that they can be regarded as ''historical'' only in the details of their execution, tasks the woman themselves regarded as dreary and of little status in the scale of human events. And yet, as we are frequently reminded, the female half of mankind must have a history: not to have a history is to be nobody. In the cause of recovering women's history, not one but two books were published this year on women in the late 18th-century: Mary Beth Norton's ''Liberty's Daughters: The Revolutionary Experience of American Women, 1750-1800'' and now Linda K. Kerber's ''Women of the Republic.''

headline: FEUDING OF BRAZIL'S CHURCH AND MILITARY GROWS BITTER
leadPara: Five months after the stirring tour of Brazil by Pope John Paul II quelled feuding between the church and the military leaders, relations between them have plunged to a new low. The issue is the same that has divided them for more than a decade: the church's increasingly militant identification with demands of the nation's poor, and the military's growing conviction that this leads priests into activities incompatible with religion.

Carlos Romero Barcelo of the New Progressive Party, which advocates statehood, barely edged out former Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon of the Popular Democratic Party. Out of 1.7 million ballots cast, the margin of victory was 3,500 votes.

headline: EX-PAPAL ENVOY IN U.S.
leadPara: Egidio Cardinal Vagnozzi, who served as Apostolic Delegate to the United States for a nine-year period during which the Second Vatican Council brought sweeping changes to the Roman Catholic Church, died in Rome on Dec. 26. He was 74 years old and at the time of his death was the the Vatican's Prefect of Economic Affairs. Cardinal Vagnozzi had 28 years of experience as a Vatican diplomat in December 1958, when Pope John XXIII appointed him papal envoy to the Catholic church in the United States. He had served as an adviser to the Apotolic Delegate in Washington from 1932 to 1942. Other Vatican assignments took him to Portugal, France and the Philippines.

headline: OUSTED GOVERNOR GETS 2D CHANCE AFTER 67 YEARS
leadPara: When Assemblyman Maurice D. Hinchey was showing some tourists around the State Capitol, he came across an unlabeled portrait on the wall that struck him as that of ''a remarkable man, intelligent, strong.'' It turned out to be a likeness of William Sulzer, the only Governor of New York to be impeached and ousted from office. The incongruity of his reaction and the man's ignominious history so struck Mr. Hinchey during that tour a couple of years ago that he began a personal investigation of the 1913 impeachment.

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS; The Wheel Of Chance
leadPara: A nasty little incident in a Paris suburb during the holidays came as a startling reminder of the way the wheel of opinion is turning. It is a grim sign of how things could go, in Europe and for the West in general; but it also gives an intriguing glimpse of a new opportunity for a sense of realism and decency in the world, out of all the illusion and demagogy. A Communist ''commando,'' evidently at the instigation of the Communist Mayor of Vitry-sur-Seine, bulldozed the entrances to an empty workers' hostel, ripping out heating, gas and electrical installations to block the arrival of ''any more immigrants in our community.'' Three hundred workers from Mali were to be moved from their dilapidated housing in the nearby town of St.-Maur-des-Fosses.
